subject: Re: [junit] creative use of JUnit
msgSnippet: ... I don t understand the way you re using the word binding here. countTestCases() counts the number of test cases in a suite. For a single TestCase object,
messageBody:
jsa@... wrote:

> Hy,
>
> I've been using JUnit for unit tests quite successfully for some time now.
> Now I've started working on a framework to test the configuration & setup
> of a running system. I've noticed several similarities between the
> framework I built and JUnit and I plan to port this framework on top of
> JUnit, now I've got some questions on the nature of JUnit that I didn't
> need to know until now.
>
> Is the number returned by Test.countTestCases() binding?

I don't understand the way you're using the word "binding" here.
countTestCases() counts the number of test cases in a suite. For a
single TestCase object, it answers 1; for a TestSuite, it counts the
Test objects it contains, recursively.

> Do current TestRunners depend on a pre-defined
> structure of the test?

I don't understand what this question means.

> Anyone got any ideas on the general design of such a beast or knows wether
> such a thing was already attempted on top of JUnit?

I don't know of any such thing.
